Award.AwardTitle: III: Small: Genome-Wide Algorithms for Haplotype Reconstruction and Beyond: A Combined Haplotype Assembly and Identical-by-Descent Tracts Approach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will develop rigorous and fast (practical) graph-theoretic genome-wide algorithms associated with genome sequence data and graphs within an integrated set of research and educational activities designed to intertwine synergistically with statistical modeling; apply these to the solution of real-world problems and long-standing computer science and mathematics questions that impact molecular biology; and make these techniques accessible to students, researchers, and practitioners in the corresponding fields. The project focuses on algorithms for haplotype reconstruction from genome sequence data of various organisms and genomes having different polyploidy number, i.e., number of haplotypes. The mammalian genomes, human included, are diploid genomes. However, the polyploidy number varies across the life spectrum from 1 (bacteria) to more than 100 (adder's-tongue fern). The HapCompass graph-theoretic framework associates genome sequencing read mappings with the genome-wide SNP data in the human genome.The HapCompass algorithm uses local optimization algorithms on the spanning tree cycle basis of HapCompass graphs for objective functions that model various measures of error correction in haplotype reconstruction. Earlier work provided a combinatorial framework for error-correction models for diploid haplotype assembly, a framework embraced by the large literature on the topic in the following decade. The fundamental case of diploid genomes and the HapCompass graph theory, data structures and algorithms set the stage for generalizations to polyploidy and integrative genome-wide haplotype reconstruction in samples of individuals that share haplotypic regions identical by descent. In addition, curriculum development is plan that covers the topics from both a computing and the user perspective. All materials and software, source code, and documentation will be available. Software will rely on the open-source model.

This project intertwines computer science with statistical models and an impact in genomics and molecular biology. Faster and more accurate algorithms for diploid haplotype assembly based on multi-criteria optimization using multiple models of error correction on the spanning-tree cycle bases of compass graphs will be developed. In addition, robust generalizations of the graph theory and algorithms for polyploid genomes that permit a common algorithmic strategy are planned. The team also is developing an optimal linear time algorithm for shared IBD tract identification in the case of phased genotype data, and efficient and exact algorithms for IBD haplotype tract identification for shared IBD tracts in unphased genotype data that are linear in the number of haplotypes and subquadratic in the number of genotypes to enhance efficiency. The final product of the work will be an algorithmic framework for genome-wide haplotype reconstruction created by combining the new algorithms and Clark Consistency Graph data structures and algorithms.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of this proposal has been to develop rigorous algorithmic theory and practical software tools for genome-wide haplotype assembly and haplotype phasing of thousands of genomes. Specifically, this proposal addressed the fundamental problem of haplotype reconstruction by a combined approach involving haplotype assembly of sequence reads and identical-by-descent (IBD) haplotype regions (tracts) into genome-wide haplotypes with algorithms that meet five axioms the PI thought are desiderata for the next generation of population genomics studies: (1) efficiency and scalability, (2) produces long haplotypes, (3) technology independent, (4) supports a variety of inputs, and (5) implements a general framework for polyploidy genomes. We developed graph theory algorithms based on graphs defined by genome sequencing reads, providing a broad algorithmic framework based on cycle-basis optimization on the constructed graphs capturing information about genomic variation and with their connectivity witnessed by sequencing reads. This builds on the work of the PI and his former PhD student Derek Aguiar, now assitant professor of computer science at the University of Connecticut. Their HapCompass algorithm is one of the leading methods to date for haplotype assembly of diploid individuals. The foundational HapCompass graph theory was expanded in the work performed in this project to include IBD sharing of haplotypes, haplotype assembly of polyploidy genomes, and to genome-wide algorithms for haplotype reconstruction using jointly haplotype assembly and IBD tracts. The HapCompass-polyploidy algorithm was designed for fast and rigorous reconstruction of the haplotypes of a polyploidy genome. The TRACTATUS algorithm was designed for fast and rigorous algorithms for genome-wide identical-by-descent haplotype tracts identification and their Fisher junctions. Algorithms for long-range (genome-wide) haplotype phasing and parents-of-origin alleles inference were also provided part of this software library of haplotype assembly tools.

The research performed led naturally onto two new research directions: (1) In work in collaboration with Doug McErlean, former student of the PI, now a software engineer at Google, advances were obtained in developing a new algorithmic theory and efficient algorithms for speeding up computation of the Maximum-Likelihood functions optimization based on their graph-theoretic symmetries with applications to the Haplotype Phasing Likelihood function and the haplotype phasing problem. And (2) Advances in developing new algorithmic theory for extending haplotype assembly algorithms developed by the PI and Derek Aguiar to the emerging class of deep computational problems with major practical impact in the area of genomic mosaicism.  The research provided avenues towards a software pipeline based on the new algorithms named e-TRACTATUS.

Two breakthroughs of the above research are highlighted here, work in collaboration with two students of the PI.

The PI work with Derek Aguiar in developing the TRACTATUS algorithm, an exact algorithm for computing all IBD haplotype tracts in time linear in the size of the input O(mn) resolves long standing open problems, on “exchangeability” and on breaking optimally the (worst-case) quadratic time barrier of O(m^2n) of previous methods often cited as a bottleneck in haplotype analysis of genome-wide association study-sized data. Here m is the number of individuals and n is the number of SNPs. This advance in algorithm efficiency makes an impact in a number of areas of population genomics rooted in the seminal Li-Stephens' framework for modeling multi-loci linkage disequilibrium (LD) patterns, with applications to the estimation of recombination rates, imputation, haplotype-based LD mapping, and haplotype phasing.

The PI work with Doug McErlean opened an exciting new avenue for research based on the elegance of the Haplotype Phasing Likelihood Function. The new algorithm COREPHASE provides a reduction of the maximum likelihood phasing problems with 2^100 variables or more to Expectation-Maximization (EM)-practical sizes without loss of global optimality via graph-theoretic symmetries of the likelihood function.

Through correspondence the PI received, HapCompass is a leading software tool package in human genetics and population genomics of humans and other organisms. Among its users:  it is used on human genomic data, in benchmark comparisons, and for other organisms (given in parentheses) at MIT, CNB-CSIC Spain, University of Rochester, Magee-Women Research Institute, Wageningen University, UC Davis, Seven Bridges Genomics, Centre for Organismal Studies (COS) Heidelberg, MedImmune (primates), University of Ottawa, University of Texas at Austin, British Columbia Centre for Disease Control (undisclosed to us target virus), Arizona State University (undisclosed to us target parasite), Cardiff University – (tetraploid earthworm), Stanford (polyploid strawberry), Dow AgroSciences (tetraploid crop), University of Gothenburg  (Caryophyllaceae),  Heidelberg University (tetraploid Arabidopsis arenosa and A. lyrata).

The following former students of the PI made essential contributions to this project through their research theses written under the PI supervision: Derek Aguiar, PhD thesis, now postdoctoral student in computer science at Princeton University; Sam Crisanto, honor  thesis, now at Microsoft Research; Daniel Seidman, honor thesis, now graduate student in computational biology at Cornell University; Youn Kim, honor thesis, now graduate student in computer science at MIT.
